docs.lead_paragraph: If you want to improve the vocabulary of your children, sign them up for the orchestra, a study released yesterday suggests. The research, which was published in the journal Neuropsychology, builds on earlier research showing that the region of the brain involved in verbal memory is larger in adult musicians than in those who are not musicians.
docs.abstract: Dr Agnes S Chan, Chinese University of Hong Kong researcher, leads study on effects of playing musical instrument on child's vocabulary; finds children with musical training scored about 20% higher on word recognition tests than those who did not; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: If you want to improve the vocabulary of your children, sign them up for the orchestra, a study released yesterday suggests.    The research, which was published in the journal Neuropsychology, builds on earlier research showing that the region of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Zeda F. Rosenberg, chief executive of the International Partnership for Microbicides, spends her days redesigning global strategies for curbing AIDS. Instead of focusing on the treatment of the disease, Dr. Rosenberg, 49, is trying to create a whole new system for stopping it, and she hopes to use women as a target population to do so.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Zeda Rosenberg; Agency Seeks a Virus-Killer for Women To Help Control the Spread of AIDS

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Zeda F Rosenberg, International Partnership for Microbicides chief executive, discusses her focus on microbicide development, which is designed to prevent women from contracting AIDS; early areas of success include pH effecting gel that creates inhospitable HIV environment, mild detergent type product that kills HIV and several inhibitors that deny HIV attachment to target cells; her approach, which is very business oriented, must overcome roadblocks of male-dominated medical research, need for longterm testing to ensure safety of product and general opposition to addressing treatment directly related to sex rather than developing vaccine; Rosenberg asserts that microbicides will be available by 2010; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Zeda F. Rosenberg, chief executive of the International Partnership for Microbicides, spends her days redesigning global strategies for curbing AIDS.    Instead of focusing on the treatment of the disease, Dr. Rosenberg, 49, is trying to create a...

docs.lead_paragraph: They are called smart pills or brain boosters or, to use the preferred pharmaceutical term, cognitive enhancers. But whatever the name given to compounds created to prevent or treat memory loss, drug companies and supplement producers -- eager to meet the demands of a rapidly growing market -- are scrambling to exploit what they view as an enormous medical and economic opportunity.

headline.main: The Race for a Pill To Save Memory

docs.abstract: Market for memory enhancers is growing as baby boomers age and become concerned about their future; pace of brain research is accelerating; Dr Paul R Solomon, Williams College psychology professor, holds that research in achieving some success in identifying brain processes and biochemical pathways involved in memory collection and storage; drug companies also see economic benefit in development of drugs suited for population with growing interest in retaining memory necessary for autonomy as they age; several drugs being tested are discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: They are called smart pills or brain boosters or, to use the preferred pharmaceutical term, cognitive enhancers.    But whatever the name given to compounds created to prevent or treat memory loss, drug companies and supplement producers -- eager to...

docs.lead_paragraph: The word fish has entered the American vocabulary in several not so savory ways. ''That's a fish tale,'' for example, and ''That smells fishy,'' suggest a highly exaggerated story or blatant lie or misdeed. But in the last two decades, fish and shellfish have enjoyed a more positive press, lauded for conveying a number of important health benefits to those who regularly dine on them.

headline.main: Tip the Scale in Favor of Fish: The Healthful Benefits Await

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column outlines health benefits and potential risks of eating fish and shellfish; American Heart Assnrecommends everyone should try to consume two fish servings per week as fish oils have been found to directly reduce risk of cardiovascular problems; omega-3 fatty acids described; column discusses risks of eating fish, such as mercury, food poisoning and allergies and gives and gives suggestions to reduce health risks; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: The word fish has entered the American vocabulary in several not so savory ways. ''That's a fish tale,'' for example, and ''That smells fishy,'' suggest a highly exaggerated story or blatant lie or misdeed.    But in the last two decades, fish and...

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of H.I.V. cases diagnosed in gay and bisexual men climbed for the third consecutive year in the United States in 2002, fueling fears that the disease might be poised for a major comeback in this high-risk group. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reported the finding today at the 2003 National H.I.V. Prevention Conference in Atlanta, also revealed that AIDS diagnoses overall had risen 2.2 percent to 42,136 last year.

headline.main: Cases of H.I.V. Rise in 2 U.S. Groups

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention representatives, addressing 2003 National HIV Prevention Conference in Atlanta, report number of HIV cases diagnosed in gay and bisexual men has risen for third consecutive year; report that overall AIDS diagnoses increased just over 2% to 42,136 last year; desire to track illness to help in understanding patterns of transmission have led to blood test that determines whether person has been infected in previous six months; test is expected to be in use by 2004 in areas that account for 93 percent of annual HIV infections (M)
docs.snippet: The number of H.I.V. cases diagnosed in gay and bisexual men climbed for the third consecutive year in the United States in 2002, fueling fears that the disease might be poised for a major comeback in this high-risk group.    The Centers for Disease...

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: An English study on autism is the first to report what appears to be a leveling off of the steep rise in new cases, the researchers say. The study, led by Dr. Brent Taylor of University College London, was published last week in The Archives of Disease in Childhood, the pediatric journal of the British Medical Association. An earlier study by Dr. Taylor had described an ''exponential'' increase in the London metropolitan region among children born from 1979 to 1992.

headline.main: Autism Cases Level Off in Britain

docs.abstract: Dr Brent Taylor, University College (London) researcher, publishes findings in Archives of Disease in Childhood that show rate of autism in Great Britain has leveled off to remain at 1992 level; critics say results are not consistent with other studies; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: An English study on autism is the first to report what appears to be a leveling off of the steep rise in new cases, the researchers say.    The study, led by Dr. Brent Taylor of University College London, was published last week in The Archives of...

docs.lead_paragraph: A good attitude may not fend off all of life's woes, but it can help you avoid catching a cold, a new study says. Researchers from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh gave 334 healthy volunteers a series of surveys that were translated into scores of positive or negative ''emotional styles'' and then squirted a virus that causes colds up the volunteers' noses.

headline.main: Right Attitudes Keep Colds at Bay

docs.abstract: Psychologist Dr Sheldon Cohen, lead researcher on study of effects of mental attitude on illness published in Psychosomatic Medicine, finds those individuals who use positive vocabulary regarding themselves are less likely to come down with colds; holds that people positive attitudes also, on average, experienced diminished symptoms when sick; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: A good attitude may not fend off all of life's woes, but it can help you avoid catching a cold, a new study says.    Researchers from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh gave 334 healthy volunteers a series of surveys that were translated into...

docs.lead_paragraph: Go ahead, loosen that tie. You could be saving your vision. A study published today in The British Journal of Ophthalmology found that wearing a tightly tied necktie had a significant effect on blood pressure within the eye, which it called the most important known risk factor for the development of glaucoma, a disease in which the optic nerve is progressively damaged.

headline.main: An Eye Peril, Around the Neck

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Ritch, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary researcher, leads study published in British Journal of Ophthalmology, that shows correlation between glaucoma and wearing tight neckties; wearing tight tie is found to raise blood pressure within eye (S)
docs.snippet: Go ahead, loosen that tie. You could be saving your vision.     A study published today in The British Journal of Ophthalmology found that wearing a tightly tied necktie had a significant effect on blood pressure within the eye, which it called the...

docs.lead_paragraph: While drug companies are competing to be the first to market a second-generation of memory enhancer, supplement manufacturers are already promoting products they maintain can improve mental fitness, although evidence supporting such claims can be slim. Even when some data suggest that product ingredients may indeed help those with memory failures, the companies frequently direct their marketing at healthy people who want to improve mental functioning.
docs.abstract: Success of memory enhancing drugs and supplements, mainly containing ginko, has spawned rush of research to develop new generation of aids for memory; effectiveness of products on market is largely unsubstantiated, but sales bring $300 million annually; possible effectiveness of supplements on portion of population not experiencing memory problems discussed (S)
docs.snippet: While drug companies are competing to be the first to market a second-generation of memory enhancer, supplement manufacturers are already promoting products they maintain can improve mental fitness, although evidence supporting such claims can be...

docs.lead_paragraph: What to eat? Sometimes it seems to be an impossible question. There are several different kinds of fats to worry about, complex and simple carbohydrates, vitamins in and out of the bottle, chickens that run free before they die and those that don't, grass or grain-fed beef.

headline.main: Does Mercury Matter? Experts Debate the Big Fish Question

docs.abstract: Article discusses many studies that have been done in past decade to try and determine potential effects of mercury on humans and establish appropriate guidelines for fish consumption based on research; notes that, variety of studies have produced variety of results and many agencies, including Food and Drug Administration and Environmental Protection Agency, publish conflicting recommendations for eating fish; Dr Roberta F White, Boston University environmental health department chairwoman and Boston Environmental Hazards Research Center director, has identified negative effects of mercury exposure on unborn children in Faeroe Islands study; backed by other studies, her data has persuaded National Academy of Sciences panel to err on side of caution and set conservative levels of acceptable fish consumption; tuna poses particular area of concern as canned tuna is most consumed fish in US; some suggest that separate guidelines could be established to help consumers make healthy choices; drawing (L)
